name: Ola
observations: full name is Olaoluwa

name: VPS
observations: Limited in compute scope to the resources and capabilities of a single machine
More or less stuck with some fixed capacity
Cannot span multiple dedicated servers
Operates on a single physical machine partition model

name: AWS EC2
observations: Distributed nature allowing access to resources that can span multiple dedicated servers
Spans across a large geographical area
Offers higher availability compared to VPS
Provides higher compute offerings than VPS
Allows for more dynamic scaling than VPS
Can dynamically allocate resources across multiple physical hosts

name: Dynamic Scaling
observations: Enabled by distributed infrastructure
Allows resources to be adjusted based on demand
More flexible than fixed capacity models

name: High Availability
observations: Achieved through geographical distribution
Enabled by spanning multiple dedicated servers
Reduces single points of failure

Trains Muay Thai on Mondays, Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Sundays
Currently arrives at gym by 6 PM
Wants to arrive earlier for training (training is 5 PM to 9 PM)
Used to arrive earlier at gym in the past
Has read the book 'Atomic Habits' by James Clear
Previously arrived at gym earlier by keeping to time more easily
Had better time management in the past for gym arrival

name: Event Sourcing
observations: Is a strategy for keeping track of all the things that happen in a system
Instead of storing current state, stores sequence of events that led to current state
Uses append-only event log where events are never deleted or updated
Current state is calculated by replaying all events from the beginning
Events describe what happened, not what the state is
Events are treated as immutable facts

name: Traditional Database Approach
observations: Stores only current state like a whiteboard that gets erased and updated
Loses all history of how the current state was reached
Uses UPDATE and DELETE operations that modify existing data
Cannot replay or reconstruct past states
Example: UPDATE users SET balance = 1247.50 WHERE id = 123

name: Event Log
observations: Append-only log that stores all events in chronological order
Events are never modified or deleted, only new events are added
Acts like a detailed notebook or journal of everything that happened
Enables complete audit trail and time travel capabilities
Similar to Git commit history for databases

name: Event Replay
observations: Process of reconstructing current state by processing all events from the beginning
Enables time travel to see system state at any point in history
Useful for debugging and understanding how system reached current state
Can create multiple views or projections from same event stream

name: Bitmap Index
observations: Has constant time O(1) equality lookups for individual values
Excels on low cardinality columns where hash indexes perform poorly
Boolean operations are linear time O(n) where n is table size
Individual row operations are super optimized through bitwise operations and sequential access
Great at optimizing queries with complex conditional logic on low cardinality columns
Not suitable for frequently changing columns
Not suitable for high cardinality columns
Uses dense bit packing for cache-friendly memory access
Can leverage hardware bit-counting instructions for aggregations

name: Hash Index
observations: Has constant time O(1) equality lookups under ideal conditions
Performs poorly on low cardinality columns due to high collision rates
With low cardinality, degrades from O(1) to O(n) due to collision chain traversal
Works well on high cardinality columns with minimal collisions
Suitable for email addresses, session tokens, user IDs, product SKUs
Not suitable for status fields, boolean columns, category codes, country codes

name: Low Cardinality Column
observations: Contains few unique values relative to total row count
Examples include status fields, boolean columns, category codes, country codes
Causes high collision rates in hash indexes
Ideal for bitmap indexes
Hash index suitability rule: Cardinality ÷ Row Count should be > 0.1

name: High Cardinality Column
observations: Contains many unique values relative to total row count
Examples include email addresses, session tokens, user IDs, product SKUs
Works well with hash indexes due to minimal collisions
Not suitable for bitmap indexes as it would require too many bitmaps
Hash index suitability rule: Cardinality ÷ Row Count should be > 0.1

name: Bitwise Operations
observations: Fundamental to bitmap index efficiency
Allows super optimized individual row operations
Enables sequential memory access patterns
Can be parallelized for better performance
Hardware-optimized in modern processors

name: Database Schema Design
observations: Single amount column with entry_type is preferred for double-entry accounting
Bitmap index on entry_type column enables fast lookups of all debits or credits
Alternative to separate debit_amount and credit_amount columns

name: Entry Type Column
observations: Contains values like 'DEBIT' or 'CREDIT'
Good candidate for bitmap indexing due to low cardinality
Used in single amount column approach for double-entry accounting

name: Double-Entry Accounting Schema
observations: Can be implemented with single amount column plus entry_type
Alternative to separate debit_amount and credit_amount columns
Both approaches maintain accounting balance requirements

name: Theorem
observations: A mathematical statement that has been proven to be true
Requires rigorous proof to establish validity
Built upon axioms and previously proven theorems
Examples include Pythagorean Theorem and theorems about prime numbers
Serves as reliable mathematical tools for future work

name: Proof
observations: Rigorous evidence of the soundness and correctness of a theorem
Step-by-step logical argument from axioms to theorem
Uses axioms, previously proven theorems, and logical rules
The process that transforms a mathematical claim into a theorem
Provides the reasoning that shows why a theorem is true

name: Axiom
observations: A statement that is assumed to be true within some context
Basic assumptions accepted without proof
Forms the foundation of mathematical systems
Self-evident or agreed-upon truths
Cannot be proven within the system they define
When an axiom has a corresponding proof, it becomes a theorem

name: Arrow Notation Function Representation
observations: Arrow notation provides a visual way to represent functions by showing mappings between domain and codomain elements
Uses arrows (→) to connect input values to their corresponding output values
Particularly effective for finite functions where all mappings can be explicitly shown

name: Function f Example with Arrow Notation
observations: Domain X = {1, 2, 3, 4}
Codomain Y = {a, b, c, d, e}
Function defined as f = {(1, b), (2, a), (3, d), (4, b)}
Range = {a, b, d}

name: Arrow Diagram Visualization
observations: Shows domain elements on the left, codomain elements on the right
Arrows connect each domain element to exactly one codomain element
Multiple arrows can point to the same codomain element
Some codomain elements may have no arrows pointing to them
Clearly distinguishes between range and codomain elements

name: Function Inverse
observations: The inverse of a function f, denoted f^(-1), is not simply a function where domain and codomain are swapped
For f^(-1) to exist as a function, f must be bijective (both one-to-one and onto)
If f: X → Y, then f^(-1): Y → X, but this requires f to be invertible
The domain of f^(-1) is the range of f, not necessarily the entire codomain of f
The codomain of f^(-1) is typically taken to be the domain of f

name: Bijective Function
observations: A function that is both one-to-one (injective) and onto (surjective)
Required condition for a function to have an inverse function
Ensures that each element in the codomain has exactly one preimage in the domain
Guarantees that the inverse relation is also a function

name: One-to-One Function
observations: Also called injective function
Each element in the codomain is mapped to by at most one element in the domain
If f(a) = f(b), then a = b
Necessary but not sufficient condition for invertibility

name: Onto Function
observations: Also called surjective function
Every element in the codomain is mapped to by at least one element in the domain
The range equals the codomain
Necessary but not sufficient condition for invertibility

name: Function Domain
observations: The set of all possible input values for a function
For f: X → Y, X is the domain
Must be clearly specified when defining a function

name: Function Codomain
observations: The set of all possible output values for a function
For f: X → Y, Y is the codomain
Contains the range but may be larger than the range

name: Function Range
observations: The set of all actual output values produced by a function
Subset of the codomain
For inverse to exist as function, range must equal codomain (onto property)

name: Well-Defined Function
observations: A function is well-defined when each input in the domain maps to exactly one output in the codomain
Well-definedness is a fundamental requirement for something to be considered a function
In set notation, for f: X → Y to be well-defined, if x ∈ X, then f(x) must have exactly one value in Y

name: Function Definition
observations: A function f: X → Y is a relation where each element in domain X is paired with exactly one element in codomain Y
The defining property of a function is that each input has exactly one output
If a mapping assigns multiple outputs to a single input, it violates the definition of a function

name: Not Well-Defined Mapping
observations: A mapping that is not well-defined assigns multiple possible outputs to at least one input
Such mappings are called multivalued functions or relations, but not functions in the strict sense
Example: if f(1) could be either 2 or 3, then f is not well-defined

name: Mathematical Relations
observations: Relations are more general than functions and can map one input to multiple outputs
Every function is a relation, but not every relation is a function
A relation becomes a function when it satisfies the well-definedness condition

name: Student's Understanding of Inverse Functions
observations: Describes inverse function as swapping first and second elements of ordered pairs
States that f^(-1): Y -> X swaps domain and codomain
Claims only bijections can have valid inverses
Explains non-injective functions would create ambiguous/non-deterministic inverses
Explains non-surjective functions would create partial inverses with unmapped elements
Concludes bijective functions produce well-defined inverses

name: Inverse Function Definition
observations: For bijective f: X -> Y, the inverse f^(-1) exists
Domain of f^(-1) is the range of f, not necessarily the full codomain
f^(-1)(y) = x if and only if f(x) = y
Composition property: f^(-1) ∘ f = I_X and f ∘ f^(-1) = I_Y

name: Bijectivity Requirement
observations: Function must be both injective (one-to-one) and surjective (onto)
Injectivity ensures each y-value corresponds to exactly one x-value
Surjectivity ensures every element in range has a preimage
Without bijectivity, inverse function does not exist

name: Common Misconceptions
observations: Thinking domain of f^(-1) is the full codomain of f rather than range of f
Confusing partial functions or relations with non-existent inverse functions
Misunderstanding the precise conditions for inverse existence

name: Injective Function
observations: An injective (one-to-one) function is a function where each element in the domain maps to a distinct element in the codomain
Formally: f is injective if f(x₁) = f(x₂) implies x₁ = x₂
Equivalently: different inputs must produce different outputs
Multiple domain elements CANNOT map to the same codomain element
Each codomain element can have at most one preimage
Injectivity is stricter than the user's 'more flexible' interpretation

name: Function Mapping
observations: In any function, each domain element maps to exactly one codomain element (well-definedness)
The question is whether multiple domain elements can map to the same codomain element
For injective functions: NO - each codomain element receives at most one arrow
For non-injective functions: YES - some codomain elements can receive multiple arrows

name: User Question Analysis
observations: User asks if injective allows 'multiple domain elements map to a single co-domain element'
This describes NON-injective behavior
User seems to conflate general function behavior with injective requirements
The 'more flexible' interpretation would actually make the function non-injective

name: genVidSubtitlesWithWhisper
observations: User's current version doesn't support -f option for subtitle format
Current help shows limited options: -i, -o, -m, -l, -b, -h
Missing subtitle format option (-f) that user is trying to use
Error message: 'Unknown option -f'
User trying to generate VTT format subtitles for CULT OF SNAKETONGUE.webm file

name: subtitle_format_issue
observations: User has outdated version of script that lacks -f format option
Current script only supports default SRT format
User needs VTT format specifically
Script needs to be updated with subtitle format support

name: auto_subtitle script
observations: Default subtitle format changed from 'srt' to 'vtt'
Bash function for automated video subtitle generation and processing
Uses OpenAI Whisper for speech-to-text transcription
Integrates with FFmpeg for video processing
Optimized for NVIDIA GPU acceleration with CUDA support
Supports hardware-accelerated encoding with NVENC
Automatically organizes files into project directories by default

name: subtitle format options
observations: Default format is now 'vtt' instead of 'srt'
Supported formats: srt, vtt, txt, tsv, json, ass, lrc
Format validation included in script
VTT format works well with web-based video players

name: file organization system
observations: Creates directory structure named after input video
Organizes original video, subtitled video, and subtitle files together
Copies original file to project directory
Generates README.md with processing details
Can be disabled with -n, --no-organize flag
Shows directory and file sizes after processing

name: GPU acceleration features
observations: Always enables NVIDIA GPU acceleration
Uses CUDA for Whisper transcription
Supports hardware video encoding with NVENC (h264_nvenc, hevc_nvenc)
Auto-selects optimal encoding for burn-in operations
Validates CUDA device availability
Reports GPU memory usage during processing

name: subtitle processing modes
observations: Supports two modes: embedded track (default) and burned-in subtitles
Embedded track mode preserves original video quality
Burn-in mode renders subtitles directly into video frames
Automatically selects appropriate subtitle codecs for different container formats
Handles subtitle format compatibility for burning operations

name: Functional Completeness
observations: The characteristic of a set of operations within some system or algebra that describes the set of operations as being a complete building block for all other operations in the target system
A set of operations is deemed functionally complete if, from it, we can describe/define all other operations within some system/context
User suggests that a set containing all operations within some mathematical domain is functionally complete
Commonly discussed in the context of logic and Boolean Algebra systems

name: Boolean Algebra
observations: A system where functional completeness can be demonstrated
Contains operations from which all other operations within the system can be defined

name: Logic Systems
observations: Context where functional completeness is often discussed
Systems where sets of operations can be evaluated for completeness
